I'm not sure about that either. Again, it's about benefit vs. cost.
Crashes don't happen that often.
If you test only with small history and a fast disk, saving of preferences is fast but since we remember every file opened, it accumulates and the size grows. And some people have sumatra (and settings file) on unpredictably slow network drives so if we keep saving periodically on main thread (as we do now) I'm pretty sure there will be people seeing the app freeze.
And if you move it to background thread, that adds complexity to ensure serialization and thread safety and making sure the save completes e.g. when user quits the app, so that we don't have half-written, corrupted preferences file. Currently prefs::Save() has to be called on main thread.

column21:
Hi Blake, thanks for the PR. In general I like it. I admit Sumatra could use visual polish. Here's how I would like to approach this.


I like your icons better than the current one. At this point I don't want to expose it as a preference option (we actually already have a way to replace a toolbar by placing toolbar_11.bmp in the same directory as sumatra.exe). Let's just use new icons. If you could create a separate PR with just that change, that would be great.


For the sake of code simplicity (and long-term maintenance), I don't want to maintain multiple tab shapes. But I also have a preference for a square, simple shape. If you could prepare a separate PR that just changes the shape of the tab to square.


I'm happy to support themes but I don't want to expose them as preferences. Adding preferences  creates a pressure for maintaining future backwards compatibility and at this point we don't yet know if this is the right/full set of settings.


Also, I think a bigger positive impact would come from having 2 (or more) built-in themes that are easy to switch between than giving the user a way to create a theme from scratch.
In concrete terms, I would welcome the following PR:

keep struct Theme
define at least 2 themes ("light" and "dark" are a good start)
add Settings/Theme menu with sub-items "Light" and "Dark" for switching between themes
More themes are also welcomed (could be e.g. based on Visual Studio Code themes).

For now I would be comfortable telling people that if they want to modify the look they have to edit the code and they could submit the theme for inclusion in Sumatra. That would keep the doors open to having full customizability in settings file in the future.
Implementation comment: currently in Sumatra we have code that tries to select colors of various things based on the Windows color theme (things like win->caption->bgColor in Tabs.cpp). That was a mistake because it complicates the code and sometimes the colors picked are really bad and there's no way for us to test all possible variations). Adding theming is a good opportunity to remove that code (basically remove support for UseSysColors setting and all the conditional code to support it).
In similar vein, there are some other things that are basically superseded by themes, like MainWindowBackground etc. There are probably more color-related settings that should be substituted but probably not all of them (the difficulty here is that we have 3 different uis (fixed page, comic book and ebook ui), which currently have different colors. Not sure if we should simplify and have theme colors apply to all of them, allow for a single theme to specify different colors for each ui or have Settings/Fixed Page Theme/, and Settings/Ebook Theme/  i.e. we have a set of themes but the 2 main UIs can have them chosen separately (comic book ui is so similar to fixed page ui that probably doesn't deserve it's own thing).
Comment on look of tabs: a common complaint is that it's hard to figure out which tab is currently selected. Colors in the screenshots are probably better than what we have currently but I think the best visual hint is when the background color of selected tab "bleeds" into the reset of the app, like in Visual Studio Code or Edge.

Finally, I'm sure there are other visual things that could be improved (like appearance of our notifications). I'm happy to merge more improvements.

Thanks for the feedback!
I have a few questions before implementing those requests:

The icon pack I used (https://material.io/icons/) looks much better with transparency, but obviously I had to modify them to work with the BMP format. I wasn't able to determine whether it is possible to switch to an image format which does support transparency. If you know that it is possible and could point me in the right direction, I'd be happy to implement that before submitting that PR.
I agree the square tabs are quite nice, however I think they would look a lot better if they were sharper. Currently, there is a distinct border surrounding the tabs which seems to be caused by some kind of anti-aliasing. I tried to change the render mode (https://github.com/sumatrapdfreader/sumatrapdf/blob/master/src/Tabs.cpp#L203) but that resulted in nothing being rendered at all. If you could point me in the right direction to fix this I'll do so, otherwise I can just submit a PR as is.
Where should I put the various theme structs (light, dark, etc)? Should I keep the current theme stored in gGlobalPrefs->theme? It seems like that would mean it is still part of the preferences file, but I also do not know how else to save current preferences. I suppose there could be a theme string in gGlobalPrefs which saves the current theme, but then the actual theme struct should be easily accessible from everywhere else, and I do not know where I would store it.
I was trying to figure out if there is a way to change the colours (background and text) of the menus. For a proper dark theme, we would need to change the menus as well, although I understand this may be difficult since you are using the Windows APIs.

column20:
To take care of: #736
I used the VS UI to modify resource.h. It seems to have created quite a mess in terms of created and modified files. Hopefully that's okay.
I realized as I went I could expand on the Theme struct quite a bit (made it more modular, added some fields) and ended up creating Theme.h and Theme.cpp because the theme stuff was quite large. I removed lots of old code in Tabs.cpp which formed the only existing theme and replaced it with a more powerful and general tab theming system.
I removed support for UseSysColors and MainWindowBackground. I removed FixedPageUI/EBookUI.TextColor/BackgroundColor and now use currentTheme->document.textColor/backgroundColor. I wasn't sure how to handle the changes in AppPrefs.cpp since the comments there already mentioned backwards compatibility and now I am completely removing those properties.
I am not sure if it was the best idea to replace FixedPageUI/EBookUI.TextColor/BackgroundColor as I did, simply because it would be nice to get default document colours even with a dark theme on. Maybe I could add another menu item under themes which enables or disables this.

There are 3 reasons I can't merge this change.
1. It changes too many unrelated things at once. If something breaks due to those changes, it'll be hard to figure out which change was responsible.
2. Passing by value vs. by reference changes semantics in a subtle way. That means that each change needs to be tested at least by stepping through the code in the debugger to make sure that changed code path have been exercised.
And that needs to be tested by the person making the change because that's the bulk of the work.
3. Most of those codepaths are not in performance sensitive code.
cppcheck is a tool to point out areas of focus but you have to apply judgement on top of that.
Looking at the changes, those that deal with std::function arguments are no-brainer.
Others, like Doc don't need changing. I even made explicit note in https://github.com/sumatrapdfreader/sumatrapdf/blob/master/src/Doc.h#L8 that it's ok to pass them by value.

column13: Do not load more than one version of comctl32.dll
column20:
The current version of SumatraPDF (git, not 3.1.2) has a bug that causes comctl32.dll to be loaded twice with different versions:

This happens on all supported versions of Windows, from XP through 10.
The cause of this is the well-intentioned but somewhat misguided NoDllHijacking(), which attempts to load comctl32.dll from the system32 directory using SafeLoadLibrary. However, at this point (and in fact, before WinMain is ever reached) comctl32.dll v6.x has long since been loaded. This is because of the explicit DLL dependency declared in the application manifest. You can verify this using a debugger such as WinDbg or x64dbg that stops at the system breakpoint.
Complicating the matter is the fact that comctl32.dll has been declared as a delay-load dependency. This means that the ntdll loader cannot be sure which, if any, additional version(s) of comctl32.dll may be requested at runtime, because it is possible to dynamically activate and deactivate Fusion (SxS) contexts.
So this commit consists of two parts:

Change comctl32.dll from a delay-load dependency to a static import.

This happens on all supported versions of Windows, from XP through 10.

column13: Remove BOM character from RTL lists
column20:
Unicode character 0xFEFF, although often presented along with the
"Arabic Presentation Forms-B" characters, is actually part of the
Specials characters, and represents the Byte Order Marker (BOM),
marking the [big]-endianness (when appearing at the beginning of a
file/stream) or a Zero Width No-Break Space (ZWNBSP) (when appearing
elsewhere).
Accordingly, it's presence in the Right-To-Left list of characters
would make texts seem more Right-to-Left oriented than they really are.
This fixes #1138, where in the table of contents of the submitted PDF
file there was a count of 57 RTL characters, all BOMs, against 4 LTR
characters, setting it's direction as Right-to-Left.

Add a button before the menu button in the caption

EnginePdf: fix memory leak when rendering is aborted
column20:
When the rendering (here in fz_run_display_list) is aborted, a memory
leak can occur as fz_close_device can throw in case of "items left on
stack in draw device".
This happens when zooming out and in.
When fz_close_device throws, fz_drop_device and fz_drop_pixmap
are not executed and so a memory leak occurs.
With this commit, if the rendering is aborted in a way that causes
fz_close_device to throw, EnginePdf::RenderPage function will
just return a null pointer as it would with any errors, without memory
leak.

@kjk
I dont find the historic registry "auto detections" as useful as they may once have been, especially as in my case Acrobat, eXchange Foxit etc are all portable apps as are my Firefox Opera Chrome etc.
The stock search invocation of Internet explorer and Edge can be easily found at given locations using
"C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe" "%2"
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft\Edge\Application\msedge.exe" "%2"
What varies considerably is the user preference for a target of google, "bing translate", "websters dictionary" and those need to be set by the user.
Those could be added as defaults but many users have their own preferences so for PDF I currently use the common
\Apps\PDF\Adobe\Reader\AcroRd32.exe" /A page=%p "%1"
\Apps\PDF\FoxitReader\FoxitReader.exe /A page=%p "%1"
\Apps\PDF\PDFXEdit8\PDFXEdit.exe /A page=%p "%1"
For browser display thats
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft\Edge\Application\msedge.exe" file://"%1#page=%p"
but for searching bing
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft\Edge\Application\msedge.exe" "string with spaces" would be very simple and for other apps %2 without quotes would also be great but I do agree it could be potentially dangerous without cheking first for a valid exe as at present.

[
    CommandLine = "https://duckduckgo.com?q=%s"
]

Which adds a "Send to duckduckgo" in External Viewers, and opens it in the default browser.
They can also add the usual form of CommandLine = path_to_exe url_with_%2 for other browsers as installed

column13: workaround for #2024: don't save partial app state during termination
column20:
See issue #2024.
Adds a global flag gDontSavePrefs so that on app exit the session state is saved by OnMenuExit and not by CloseWindow.
Notes:

if gDontSavePrefs is set, all prefs are prevented from being saved by CloseWindow (also those apart from just the session state).  But it's probably fine as it looks like there are no relevant setting updates after we start to close the windows...
CloseWindow tries to save the window position/size with RememberDefaultWindowPosition which won't get picked up if the flag is set, but actually RememberSessionState will have already done that for all open windows so that's ok. And by my local tests the window sizes are in fact correctly remembered when launched the next time.

Feedback welcome!

column13: Lazy decompression of images in archives
column20:
Greatly decreases startup time and memory consumption for archive files.

column21:
I have to think about it. I agree with the goal of speeding cbx up.
It makes opening and use in non-continuous mode faster.
However, switching to continuous mode pays the price for that and in a blocking fashion, which is not good experience. Especially on slow drives (I'm testing on a network drive, where it can take seconds to load and decompress the whole file).
It could be improved for continuous case.
For example, on cbx open we could kick off a thread to load & decompress images to get their dimensions and cache them on Engine. We don't have to decompress the whole file, the first 1 kb would be enough.
That way, by the time we need the information, it might already be there.
Still wouldn't help the case when we open in non-continuous mode, as we would need this info right away.
To help with that we could cache mediabox and contentbox in per-file settings, which would speed up opening a file the second time. That could speed up opening of other formats as well.

column13: Truncate long file names in File menu (fixes #783)
column20:
Fixes a long standing (albeit low priority) issue where long file names expand the File menu too much:

Here's how it looks after these changes:


This isn't a trivial operation; we can't just count characters and split the string when we reach a threshold. Different characters have different widths, some glyphs are composed of multiple characters. So it's best to offload this work to the system itself.
Therefore, this was implemented via DrawText(), similar to how the start page truncates file names. However, the menu doesn't have a hWnd or a hdc readily available â€“ and after some hours of searching, I couldn't figure out how to get a reference to either. So I settled for the next best thing: creating a new device context, and replicating the default menu font there. It's somewhat lengthy code, but it seems to do the job. Since it's my first time working this closely with Win32 API, I might have missed some easier ways to do things; I apologize in advance.
The only potential issue I can think of is that I never call DeleteDC for that created device context. It's a dummy device context just to measure text in a given font, so it doesn't really need to be recreated every time the menu is opened; so I believe it should only need to be deleted when the application is closed entirely, by which point I would assume that memory would be freed anyway. Please let me know if that is not the case.
Sorry for the long text! Hopefully it's been useful :)

@kjk

I think limiting the string by character count is better.

It's definitely a possibility; I'd seen this SO answer stating that UTF-8 was built with this in mind, and makes it easy to check if you're splitting a character in half or not. There were a couple reasons I went for the other approach, though:

Wide characters can make the list look very jagged. A file name with thin characters can ends up significantly smaller than one with wide characters. For example, 'i's and 'W's in the screenshot below. The bounding rectangle does not have this issue.
Some characters are made up of multiple codepoints (e.g. emojis come to mind, but possibly also chars in other scrips). When splitting by a fixed threshold, they can end up broken. For example, file (7) below should end with a 'ðŸ‘‰', but ends with a tofu instead. Using the system's own DrawText() to truncate text fixes this.

These are set to truncate at 60 chars:



Have you checked how other programs on Windows (e.g. Notepad++ or Adobe Reader) handle this?

That's a great idea! It didn't occur to me.
Notepad++ and Sublime Text 3 don't seem to truncate filenames at all ðŸ¥´
Visual Studio does what you suggested: they add an ellipsis in the middle of the file name. It also seems like it's generating a tofu for file (2), however their list is not as jagged; there has to be some sort of bounding box at play here:

Didn't check Adobe Reader because I'm in a bit of a rush at the moment, but I could try looking for more examples in the wild tomorrow to get a feel of the industry standard on this.
Either way, I support the simpler idea, or perhaps a best-of-both-worlds approach. Eager to hear your input on it :)

Perfect can be enemy of good.
The simple implementation is to cut WCHAR characters from the middle.
It's true that some glyphs are represented as 2 WCHAR characters and cutting just one of them would generate imperfect text but that would be very rare. I'm not even sure if such characters are allowed in file names.

I'm fine with the simple implementation.

column13: Support lazyload when restore session
column20:
Lazy load session tabs when startup untill switch to the target tab for lower mem usage and speed up.
When select other tabs, there will be a highlight message "Please wait - rendering..." before the document is loaded (using ReloadDocument).
User may change lazyloadWhenRestore setting to disable it.
In the future we may add scheduled load in background (but will increase mem usage so better make it optional) #2565, or add a DisplayModel with lazyload support for better code structure.
#1497

LoadDocument and e.g. LoadDocumentRest


in LoadDocument

show a notification Loading ${filePath}
